awd_titl_txt: Critical Assessment of the Three-dimensional (3D) Standard Model of Solar Eruptions Using a Data-driven MagnetoHydroDynamic (MHD) Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Theoretical models of solar eruptions are supported by numerical MHD calculations that use simple magnetic and velocity fields.  The Sun, however, is much more complex, and it is therefore unclear whether models that work under ideal conditions resemble on the actual Sun.  The aim of this three-year research project is to test a popular model of solar eruptions, "the standard 3D model," under realistic conditions by modeling real eruptions using photospheric observations to drive active-region-scale coronal MHD simulations.  The project team will devote a significant amount of time and effort to compare their numerical simulations to real solar observations.  The research study will have three parts: (i) perform data-driven MHD simulations; (ii) compare the simulations with observations; and, (iii) use the simulations to test predictions of "the standard 3D model."  For a sample of eruptive regions, the project team will construct nonlinear force-free extrapolations from vector magnetograms, about an hour before each eruption.  These extrapolations will be used to initialize the zero-beta MHD simulations driven by flow maps inferred from spectro-polarimetric data using optical-flow methods that treat the induction equation consistently.  The team will also model a set of non-eruptive regions as an important control: they will aim to demonstrate that their method does not produce eruptions when none occurs in reality.  They will use their simulations to test the predictions of "the standard 3D model" regarding the instability mechanism responsible for eruption (e.g., torus instability) and mode of reconnection during the eruption (e.g., slipping reconnection).  The inclusion of control regions will indicate whether or not these features are essential for an eruption to occur, and not just simply being present but remain unimportant during the eruption process.  The team will identify the instability mechanism, sites and nature of reconnection in their simulations.

To date, "the standard 3D model" of solar eruptions has been tested extensively using MHD simulations with simple bipolar magnetic fields.  This three-year research project takes the important next step to test the model under realistic conditions.  The intellectual merit of this work is to establish the viability of "the standard 3D model."  The project also aims to provide new physical insight into the basic mechanisms of magnetic energy storage and release in the solar atmosphere, which are important in a general astrophysical context.  A novel aspect of the research project is the significant amount of work devoted to validating the data-driven MHD simulations; although this type of simulations is becoming increasing common in recent years, their validation is typically of a secondary consideration and it often relies on by-eye comparisons between EUV loops and field lines from the simulation, for example.  The project team will devote a significant amount of time and effort to developing metrics for making quantitative comparisons between simulations and observations, which is a necessary step for objective validation.

The anticipated results of this three-year project will be of interest to the space weather community: an improved understanding of solar eruptions will also improve our predictive capability for these events.  The methodology and metrics for comparing numerical simulations to real observations that will be developed as part of this project will be of general use to the solar community; the project team will make their tools available to the broader community online.  All their project data will be made available to the public too.  The team also plans to organize a special session at the SHINE Workshop in the last year of the project focused on critically assessing the 3D standard model using different MHD models.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Solar eruptions are the sudden ejection of plasma and magnetic fields from the Sun's outer atmosphere, the solar corona. They are a spectacular example of solar activity and are major drivers of space weather at Earth and in the heliosphere. Eruptions are understood to be the result of the explosive reconfiguration of magnetic fields in the corona, however the exact mechanism is poorly understood.

The goal of this project was to test a particular model of eruptions called the "the standard 3D model" using Magneto-HydroDynamic (MHD) simulations of solar active regions initialized with NonLinear Force-Free-Field (NLFFF) extrapolations. MHD/NLFFF simulations treat the corona as a magnetized fluid. Since, the equations of the MHD/NLFFF model are nonlinear, they can only be solved numerically. These simulations, in principle, are a tool to study the physics of solar eruptions on a computer. However, this assumes that the simulations are an accurate model of the real Sun. Is this assumption correct? How can we test it? This is the "validation problem" for coronal magnetic field models, and a major focus of this project was trying to address this problem. Validation of coronal magnetic field models is further complicated by the fact that the relevant variable -- the coronal magnetic field -- is presently not well constrained observationally. This is a major challenge for validation that we addressed with a new approach: Bayesian hypothesis testing.

Specifically, we developed two approaches to model validation. The first was based on a Bayesian hypothesis testing framework for comparing simulations with observations of the corona in X-rays and Extreme Ultra Violet (EUV). Bayesian methods assign a probability to a hypothesis/model that reflects how well the hypothesis/model explains some set of data. We specifically focused on comparisons between X-ray images, and the line-of-sight integrated electric currents of the MHD/NLFFF model, which serves as a proxy for X-ray emission. Although this is a crude approximation, we found that these comparisons can be used to rank models in terms of how well they reproduce the observations. However, the use of such a simple proxy is a potential source of uncertainty in the comparison. An advantage of the Bayesian approach is that this uncertainty can be incorporated into the comparison. Addressing the validation problem for coronal magnetic field modeling is an important goal, and this work is a step towards achieving this.

Our second approach was to develop measures of self consistency, i.e. how well are the equations of the model actually solved? We developed a new metric for measuring the amount of magnetic charge present in a simulation, i.e. divergence of the magnetic field. One advantage of this new metric over existing ones is that it gives consistent results at different numerical resolutions.  Since magnetic charges (monopoles) are not observed in reality, their presence is an unphysical byproduct of the numerical approximation. This charge needs to be quantified, as it speaks to the reality of the simulation -- too much, and the simulation is not a useful model for understanding the real Sun. This new metric is one approach to doing this, which has already found applications in other projects.

It is well known that the boundary (input) data for NLFFF extrapolations are inconsistent with the force-free model; they are derived from spectro-polarimetric observations that infer the magnetic field at a height in the solar atmosphere where forces are significant. Thus, motivated by the goal of model validation, we sought to quantify the effects of this well-known uncertainty.  We examined the effects of this inconsistency by applying the NLFFF extrapolation model to boundary conditions derived from a simple analytic test case for which we can control the forces by varying a single parameter. The resulting NLFFF models were then quantified for the effect of this inconsistency for different levels of forcing in the boundary. We found that the effect of the inconsistency depended  on the complexity of the magnetic field: more complex fields were less well represented by a force-free model in terms of energy and structure. This particular effort involved an undergraduate student through the University of Colorado /Boulder Solar Alliance Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, and provided a significant opportunity for training.

The question of whether a solar eruption will produce just electromagnetic output (flares) or a mass ejection, is key.  An effort that was part of Pei-Hsuan Lin's PhD studies at Nagoya University (Japan) asked whether we can use coronal field modeling to discriminate between the two event outcomes, specifically by identifying certain structures ("magnetic flux ropes") and quantifying their relationship with the surrounding magnetic fields.  The answer is a definitive "maybe"; certain approaches and methods could show promise in a particular target, but when applied to more than 50 other targets and energetic events, the results were mixed.  This work provided a significant opportunity for training, resulting in a PhD degree.
